title: British accountancy firm Ernst & Young 'used black market gold to launder dirty money'
text:
A British accountancy firm covered up evidence of smuggling by a crime gang using black market gold to launder dirty money, it was claimed today.

Ernst & Young (EY) allegedly failed to report evidence of smuggling, according to an investigation by BBC Panorama and the French news agency Premieres Lignes.

The crime gang were said to have collected cash from drug dealers across Britain and Europe before laundering it by buying and selling black market gold.

Amjad Rihan, lead auditor for EY in Dubai at the time, told the BBC's Panorama that he wanted to report the suspicious activity but bosses told him not to - and watered down his reports

Documents revealed a firm owned by a member of the gang, Renade International, sold 3.6 tonnes of gold to the refinery and trading business Kaloti Group in 2012.

The following year EY was asked to conduct a review of Kaloti's supply chain compliance, and found Kaloti had paid out $5.2billion (£4.1billion) in cash in 2012.

However, EY allegedly failed to report the suspicious activity to the money laundering authorities, with $146million (£114million) of that cash going to Renade.

Both EY and Kaloti deny wrongdoing, but it is also claimed EY helped to cover up the export to Dubai of gold bars disguised as silver bars to avoid export limits on gold.

The audit team were allegedly shown what appeared to be Moroccan bars of silver, but found they were really gold bars coated silver after scratching the surface.

A reconstruction of a drug gangster handing dirty money to money launderer's mule features in the Panorama documentary which is due to air on BBC One tonight

The BBC and Premieres Lignes have now discovered the smuggled gold was also owned by Renade International.

Panorama has seen drafts of an initial compliance report to a Dubai regulator, with Kaloti saying: 'We acknowledge an incident…with the bars coated with silver'.

But EY is claimed to have rewritten the report so that it said: 'We acknowledge transactions… in which there were certain documentary irregularities.'

Amjad Rihan, lead auditor for EY in Dubai at the time, claimed he wanted to report the suspicious activity but bosses told him not to - and watered down his reports.

In the documentary, which is due to air on BBC One tonight, he claimed: 'If you identify a suspicious transaction you should report it to the authorities.

Ernst & Young (EY), whose officers at 1 More London Riverside in the capital are pictured on October 2, said the firm delivered its findings to the relevant regulator in Dubai

'What we identified was way beyond suspicion. Instead of reporting the crimes that I told them about, my bosses just covered them up'.

EY declined to comment to Panorama about the rewriting of the report, but a spokesman said the firm delivered its findings to the relevant regulator in Dubai.

It said: 'It was the work of EY Dubai that brought to light Kaloti's non-compliance with the applicable regulations and ultimately resulted in the remediation of the issues.

'More recently, and many years after these events, Mr Rihan has raised certain unfounded allegations in a legal claim which is being vigorously defended'.

Under the proceeds of crime legislation, accountants have a legal duty to report any suspicious activity to the police.

EY said that Mr Rihan, pictured in the BBC Panorama documentary, has 'raised certain unfounded allegations in a legal claim which is being vigorously defended'

In its legal dispute with Mr Rihan, EY admits that the disguised gold 'provided reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting….money laundering'.

However, the firm has claimed it did not have to report this to police because its auditors were not carrying out accountancy work at Kaloti.

Kaloti said that it had conducted all appropriate anti-money laundering checks.

A spokesman said: 'Kaloti would not knowingly enter into a trading relationship with any party in the knowledge that such party had been engaged in financial impropriety or criminal activity of any kind.

'It is categorically denied that Kaloti purchased gold coated in silver from Renade, or anyone else for that matter.'

Kaloti added that cash payments were common in Dubai, but it no longer buys gold for cash.

Panorama: Following the Drug Money will be shown on BBC One tonight at 8.30pm
description: Ernst & Young (EY) allegedly failed to report evidence of smuggling, according to an investigation by BBC Panorama and the French news agency Premieres Lignes.
